Comment: This is incorrect.  The [Real ID](https://www.dhs.gov/xlibrary/assets/real-id-act-text.pdf), as currently defined, does not meet the requirements for the proposed voter ID law because it is ***not*** all about "is this person a citizen."  A real ID is available to anyone with "legal status" which is defined as:  >(i) is a citizen or national of the United States;  >(ii) is an alien lawfully admitted for permanent or temporary residence in the United States;  >(iii) has conditional permanent resident status in the United States;  >(iv) has an approved application for asylum in the United States or has entered into the United States in refugee status;  >(v) has a valid, unexpired nonimmigrant visa or nonimmigrant visa status for entry into the United States;  >(vi) has a pending application for asylum in the United States;  >(vii) has a pending or approved application for temporary protected status in the United States;  >(viii) has approved deferred action status; or  >(ix) has a pending application for adjustment of status to that of an alien lawfully admitted for permanent residence in the United States or conditional permanent resident status in the United States.  In other words, every Real ID that has already been issued (and any that is currently authorized ***to*** be issued under any state law) is useless for proving citizenship, thus useless for the proposed voter ID law.
